Eh, can't complain about a hard counter.
  
Thing is: I disagree with those saying [Counterpell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterpell) needs a reprint, but I agree when they say [Cancel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cancel) isn't an acceptable replacement.
  
Hard counters are (against everything I like in MTG) a good thing.
  
They help balance the game in an infinite number of ways.
  
Things like [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak) (most cases it's a hard counter, but it can sometimes be overcome), [Deprive](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deprive) (hard counter that returns a land to your hand, which has been shown as a combo enabler itself), or [Stoic Rebuttal](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stoic Rebuttal) (hard counter, but is cheaper under certain conditions) are exceptional.
  
![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) to stop a player from doing anything is harsh.
  
When there are conditional counters that are actually decent, I can approve of those.
  
I feel that the delicate line between [Counterspell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterspell) and [Cancel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cancel) should be where they print counterspells.

Mana Leak may seem better, considering it has the same function, but in some situations it's better to use Cancel. Sure, Mana Leak's quite decent, but against ramp decks, they're pretty much useless. Counterspell just kinda takes the fun out of the game, considering how little it costs.
